abstract.p: Elise Langan letter says Sept 9 article on Sen Daniel Patrick Moynihan's scholarly endeavors typifies gap between academe and real world

block.p: The critique of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's scholarly endeavors by Frances Fox Piven, a political science professor, quoted in a Sept. 9 Arts & Ideas pages article, typifies the gap between academe and the real world. Mired in political correctness, the university is no longer an arena for honest debate, a hallmark of Mr. Moynihan's career.

The critique of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's scholarly endeavors by Frances Fox Piven, a political science professor, quoted in a Sept. 9 Arts & Ideas pages article, typifies the gap between academe and the real world. Mired in political correctness, the university is no longer an arena for honest debate, a hallmark of Mr. Moynihan's career.

Your article reports that Ms. Piven views Mr. Moynihan's political life as an impediment to sound research, but let's consider the alternative: political agendas not driven by principles but by polling results. While Mr. Moynihan may have rarely been published in academic journals reviewed by his ''peers,'' he has been an architect of change.
I, along with many New Yorkers, rue the day when Senator Moynihan retires and deprives us of his strength of character.
